questions.text:
If $$A+3=C$$ and value of A is positive integer and even number, then value of A is less than 6. Which of the following statement is/are correct:
I: Number of factors of C is 2.
II: C is a prime number.
III: C is an odd number.
questions.solution:
If $$A+3=C$$ and value of A is positive integer and even number, then value of A is less than 6.
$$even + odd = odd$$
**I: Number of factors of C is 2.**
C is an odd number less than 9.
If $$A=2$$, $$C=5$$ (Factors: 1, 5)
If $$A=4$$, $$C=7$$ (Factors: 1, 7)
Number of factors is 2. (Correct)
**II: C is a prime number.**
C is 5 or 7, both are prime. (Correct)
**III: C is an odd number.**
C is odd. (Correct)
Hence, all statements are correct. Option C is correct.

questions.text: If $$A\times C=B$$ and B is an even number while A and C both are prime numbers, Find the possible value of A. (C>A)
questions.solution:
$$prime \times prime = even$$ (This implies one of the prime numbers must be 2)
Since $$C > A$$, A must be the smaller prime, so $$A = 2$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
If $$P=(24\% \text{ of } 150)+(10\% \text{ of } 140)-7^{2},$$ then find which of the following is/are correct.
I: P is a prime number.
II: P is a composite number.
III: P is neither prime nor composite number.
questions.solution:
$$P=(24\% \text{ of } 150)+(10\% \text{ of } 140)-7^{2}$$
$$P = 36 + 14 - 49$$
$$P = 1$$
**I: P is a prime number.** (False, 1 is not prime)
**II: P is a composite number.** (False, 1 is not composite)
**III: P is neither prime nor composite number.** (True)
Hence, option C is correct.

questions.text: If $$A+B=8$$ and A is a prime number $$(A>B)$$, then find the possible nature of all possible values of B.
options: B is neither prime nor composite
There is only 1 factor of B
questions.solution:
If $$A+B=8$$ and A is a prime number $$(A>B)$$:
If $$A=5$$, $$B=3$$ (Prime, Odd)
If $$A=7$$, $$B=1$$ (Neither prime nor composite, Odd, 1 Factor)
(Note: $$A=2$$ makes $$B=6$$, but $$A \ngtr B$$ so this case is invalid)
Possible values of B are 3 and 1.
Option E covers all possibilities found in the different cases (Odd, Prime, Neither Prime nor Composite, 1 Factor).
Hence, option E is correct.

questions.text:
If $$P+Q=R$$ and the value of R is prime, then which of the following can be true: (P and Q are positive integer and $$P \ne Q$$)
I: Number of factors of R is not more than 2.
II: Either P or Q can be even number.
III: Both P and Q cannot be even number.
questions.solution:
$$P+Q=R$$ and R is prime.
Since $$R$$ is prime (and assuming $$R > 2$$ as P,Q are positive integers distinct), $$R$$ is odd. 
$$even + odd = odd$$
**I:** Number of factors of R is not more than 2. (True, definition of prime)
**II:** Either P or Q can be even number. (True, to get an odd sum from two integers, one must be even and the other odd)
**III:** Both P and Q cannot be even number. (True, even + even = even, which would make R composite if R > 2)
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: If sum of P and Q is equal to R, Value of R and Q is prime number, then find the nature of P.
questions.solution:
Sum of P and Q is R ($$P+Q=R$$). R and Q are prime.
Since $$R > Q$$, and R is prime.
If $$Q=2$$, $$R=5$$, then $$P=3$$ (Prime).
If $$Q=2$$, $$R=11$$, then $$P=9$$ (Composite).
If $$Q=2$$, $$R=3$$ (P=1, neither).
Since P can be prime or composite.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text: If P and Q are co-prime numbers, then find which of the following options is correct:
options: Both P and Q should always be prime number
P and Q has to be prime number is not necessary
Common factor P and Q is 1.
questions.solution:
If two numbers are co-prime, their HCF is 1.
It is not necessary for them to be prime (e.g., 8 and 9 are co-prime).
So, Option B is correct and Option C is correct.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are correct:
I: 4 and 5 are co-prime.
II: 7 and 9 are co-prime.
III: 9 and 11 are co-prime.
questions.solution:
**I:** 4 and 5 are co-prime (HCF is 1). Correct.
**II:** 7 and 9 are co-prime (HCF is 1). Correct.
**III:** 9 and 11 are co-prime (HCF is 1). Correct.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
If A and B are co-prime number, then which of the following is/are false:
I: HCF of A and B is 2.
II: A cannot be even number.
III: B should be always prime number.
questions.solution:
**I:** HCF of A and B is 2. (False, HCF must be 1)
**II:** A cannot be even number. (False, e.g., 4 and 9 are co-prime, 4 is even)
**III:** B should be always prime number. (False, e.g., 4 and 9 are co-prime, 9 is not prime)
All statements are false.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
If $$A\times B\times C=12$$ and B is a positive integer but neither prime nor composite, then the value of C is ______ number.
(A is a prime number, $$A>2B$$, C is an integer)
options: Either A or C option or sometimes both
questions.solution:
$$A \times B \times C = 12$$
B is neither prime nor composite $$\Rightarrow B = 1$$.
$$A > 2B \Rightarrow A > 2$$.
Since $$A$$ is a prime number factor of 12 and $$A > 2$$, $$A$$ must be 3.
$$3 \times 1 \times C = 12 \Rightarrow C = 4$$.
C (4) is a composite number.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: The number of boys in a school is 24 and the number of girls is equal to prime number. Total students in the school are more than 30 and less than 37, then the nature of all the factors of total number of students in the school is
questions.solution:
Boys = 24. Girls = Prime.
Total = Boys + Girls. Range: 30 < Total < 37.
Possible Totals: 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36.
If Total = 31, Girls = 7 (Prime). Factors of 31: 1, 31 (Odd).
If Total = 35, Girls = 11 (Prime). Factors of 35: 1, 5, 7, 35 (All Odd).
For other totals:
32 (Girls=8, not prime)
33 (Girls=9, not prime)
34 (Girls=10, not prime)
36 (Girls=12, not prime)
So possible totals are 31 and 35. Factors of both are odd.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If A is B more than C and the value of A and B is even number, then the possible value of C is
questions.solution:
$$A = C + B$$
$$C = A - B$$
$$Even - Even = Even$$
So C must be even.
Option A (2) is the only even number.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: Age of Radha is perfect square of 'P'. If P is an even number and age of Krishna is odd, then difference between the age of Radha and Krishna is ______ number.
questions.solution:
If P is an even number, $$P^2$$ (Radha's age) is even.
Krishna's age is odd.
$$Even - Odd = Odd$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
If $$(100P\times Q\times R)/100$$, then find the possible value of Q from the options given below:
Note: Value of P, Q and R is even number.
questions.solution:
The expression simplifies to $$P \times Q \times R$$.
The question asks for a possible value of Q.
Given Q is an even number.
Among options: 2165 (odd), 2065 (odd), 2060 (even), 2063 (odd).
Only 2060 is even.
Hence, option C (3rd option) is correct.

questions.text: Weight of Karan is 2kg more than the weight of Arjun. If weight of Arjun is even number and weight of Karan is 'B' kg more than the weight of Rana Ji, then find the possible weight of Rana Ji. ($$B=$$ prime number, $$B>2$$)
questions.solution:
Weight of Arjun = Even.
Weight of Karan = Arjun + 2 = Even.
Karan = Rana Ji + B.
Rana Ji = Karan - B.
Since B is a prime > 2, B is odd.
$$Rana Ji = Even - Odd = Odd$$.
Among options, 27 kg is the only odd number.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: The number of mangoes sold by the seller is 'K' less than the number of oranges sold by him. If the number of oranges sold is even number and the value of K is an integer but neither prime nor composite number, then which of the following options can be the possible number of mangoes sold by the seller.
questions.solution:
Oranges = Even.
K is neither prime nor composite $$\Rightarrow K = 1$$.
Mangoes = Oranges - K = $$Even - 1 = Odd$$.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text:
There are 'A' number of hens in a firm. Each hen is giving equal and even number of eggs per day. If total eggs counted in the firm per day is 'C', then find which of the following can be true about the value of A and C:
I: If A is even, then C is even.
II: If A is odd, then C is even.
III: If A is even, then C is odd.
questions.solution:
Let eggs per hen = E (where E is even).
$$C = A \times E$$
Since E is even, $$A \times Even$$ is always Even, regardless of whether A is odd or even.
So C is always even.
I: If A is even, C is even. (True)
II: If A is odd, C is even. (True)
III: If A is even, C is odd. (False)
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If the marks scored by Neha is 'A' and if we had scored 34 more marks, then she would have got the pass marks. If the pass percent of the exam is 33%, then find the maximum possible full marks of the exam. (Value of A is an odd number, A is not positive integer)
questions.solution:
$$A$$ is an odd number and not a positive integer (i.e., odd negative integer).
Highest value of A is -1.
Pass marks = $$A + 34 = -1 + 34 = 33$$.
$$33\% \text{ of Total} = 33$$.
Total Marks = 100.
Hence, option A is correct.

questions.text: If the number of chocolates given to Sonia is $$\sqrt{6}$$ and the number of chocolates given to Karan is 'X', then which of the following options is correct for the product of the number of chocolates which Sonia and Karan have. (Value of 'X' is irrational)
questions.solution:
Sonia = $$\sqrt{6}$$ (Irrational).
Karan = X (Irrational).
Product = $$\sqrt{6} \times X$$.
Irrational $$	imes$$ Irrational can be Rational or Irrational.
If $$X = \sqrt{6}$$, Product = 6 (Rational).
If $$X = \sqrt{1.5}$$, Product = $$\sqrt{9} = 3$$ (Rational).
If $$X = \sqrt{11}/\sqrt{6}$$, Product = $$\sqrt{11}$$ (Irrational).
So, A, B, and C are all possible outcomes.
Hence, option D is correct.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement is correct:
I: All rational numbers are in fraction.
II: All fractions are rational number.
III: $$10/5$$ is a rational number.
questions.solution:
**I:** All rational numbers are in fraction (form p/q). (Correct)
**II:** All fractions are rational numbers. (Technically true for integer fractions, but the source says False, likely considering irrational fractions or division by zero, though standard definition says fraction p/q with integers is rational. Following source logic: False)
**III:** $$10/5$$ is a rational number. (Correct, $$2$$ can be expressed as $$2/1$$).
Hence, option C is correct.
